Words including email, mobile and Facebook are in decline, it said. They are being replaced by the likes of Instagram, Snapchat and emoji. And the word television has now been superseded by phone. The report also notes a sudden new arrival in children's sentences. The use of the hashtag symbol # to add an extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence has become commonplace. #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta at the Oxford University Press said: "This has been a significant change in usage in this year, 2015. "Children have extended its [#] use from a simple prefix or as a search term for Twitter to an editorial device to add drama or comment." Other words on the technological endangered list are iPod, mp3 and Blackberry. The Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island poses a "growing threat", researchers at the University of Bristol say. The volcano, located 49 km (30 miles) from the Sendai nuclear plant, is also close to Kagoshima, a city of 600,000. Sakurajima's last deadly eruption was in 1914, when 58 people died. The Japanese archipelago, which sits on the Pacific "Ring of fire", has more than 100 volcanoes. Sakurajima regularly spews ash and there are many small explosions there each year, with the latest eruption being in February. It is closely monitored by Japanese authorities and one of two volcanoes at Level 3 out of 5 levels in Japan's volcanic warning system, which means that people are warned not to to approach the volcano. "The 1914 eruption measured about 1.5km cubed in volume," said the study's lead author Dr James Hickey, who has now joined the University of Exeter's Camborne School of Mines. This action is part of a broader campaign targeting Islamic clothing and symbols in the predominantly Muslim region. While the Chinese government attributes recent attacks to Uighur militants, activists argue that the violence stems from Chinese repression. Traditionally practicing a moderate form of Islam, Uighurs have recently been influenced by stricter interpretations from the Gulf and Pakistan, leading to increased face covering among women. The Chinese authorities view wearing an Islamic face veil as an act of defiance during a period of escalating regional tensions. Similar to a previous ban in Karamay prohibiting men with long beards from boarding buses, these restrictions have drawn criticism. Experts like James Leibold suggest such measures might inadvertently strengthen the veil's significance as a symbol of resistance and ethnic identity. The Communist party has explicitly linked certain Islamic dress styles to religious extremism. The law in Urumqi is pending approval from a regional body. China has launched a crackdown in the region, arresting numerous individuals and attributing recent violent incidents to Uighur militants potentially supported by overseas terror groups. Uighur activists, however, contend that China's aggressive tactics, including cultural and religious suppression, are intensifying existing tensions.

They recommended that the force implement improvement strategies more quickly while maintaining service effectiveness. During their packed day of public commitments, the Royal couple first toured the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. This Unesco World Heritage Site comprises approximately 40,000 substantial black basalt columns emerging from the sea. It marked their inaugural visit to Northern Ireland's most renowned tourist destination. The causeway originated when molten rock was thrust through earth fissures, creating a lava plateau. Subsequently, they travelled to Bushmills village to commemorate local soldier Robert Quigg, who earned a Victoria Cross for exceptional bravery during the Battle of the Somme. Sgt Quigg received the highest military honour after courageously venturing into enemy fire to locate his commanding officer. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh unveiled a statue and commemorative stone, with Quigg's grandnephew Leonard delivering a brief address. They then attended a reception at Portrush Golf Club, hosted by the Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council mayor. Afterwards, they embarked on a nostalgic journey aboard a steam train from Coleraine to Bellarena. Substantial crowds gathered in Coleraine to welcome the couple onto the five-carriage 1932 train, accompanied by local schoolchildren. Upon arriving in Bellarena, the Queen officially opened the village's new train station. This route held special significance, as they had previously travelled the same historic Coleraine to Londonderry line in 1953, the year of her coronation. The original station had opened a century earlier in 1853. Following a £46m railway line upgrade, two new platforms were introduced in Bellarena, which the Queen commemorated by unveiling a plaque. Wellwishers lined the route, waving union flags and cheering enthusiastically. The visit was part of a series of recent high-profile royal visits to Northern Ireland, following appearances by the Prince of Wales, Duchess of Cornwall, and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. Their last previous visit was in June 2014.

The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) highlighted significant disparities in child development between London and the north of England. The think tank's report, set to be launched in Sheffield, revealed that only 47% of children from the poorest families in northern England achieved a good level of early years development, compared to 59% in London. Despite this challenge, the research also showed that northern city-regions have nearly as many well-qualified individuals (3.6 million) as London (3.7 million), with projected increases in skilled worker demand. The IPPR proposed 11 benchmarks for the government's northern powerhouse initiative, emphasizing the need to address the developmental gap in children under five. IPPR's director Ed Cox stressed the importance of investing in human capital, education, and training to create a successful regional economy. He argued that devolving economic powers across the North could support more productive and sustainable growth, creating well-paying jobs and shared opportunities. The Department for Education acknowledged its commitment to helping children reach their potential, noting that 250,000 more pupils in the north are now in good or outstanding schools since 2010. The government also indicated additional funding for early years providers to help children from disadvantaged backgrounds and narrow the attainment gap.

The company's desperate efforts to manage the situation reveal a timeline of escalating problems: On 2 August, Samsung unveiled the Galaxy Note 7 in New York with great excitement, featuring innovative technologies like an iris scanner. Initial reception was positive, with the device positioned as a strong competitor to the upcoming iPhone 7. By 19 August, sales began in ten markets including South Korea and the United States. On 24 August, the first reports of device explosions emerged, quickly followed by numerous user-generated images and videos showing phones overheating and catching fire. By 2 September, Samsung initiated a global recall of 2.5 million phones due to battery defects, offering refunds or replacements. On 8 September, aviation authorities worldwide banned the device on flights. The US Consumer Product Safety Commission urged users to stop using the phone, issuing a formal recall by 15 September. Despite initial attempts to resume sales in South Korea on 1 October, problems persisted. On 6 October, replacement phones also began experiencing similar issues, with a Southwest Airlines flight evacuated after a device started smoking. By 9 October, major US carriers stopped selling and replacing the phone. Finally, on 11 October, Samsung completely halted sales and instructed all users to power down their devices while investigating the ongoing problems.

John McCormack continued driving an articulated lorry for 30 miles after colliding with another vehicle on the A9, with three children present in the car at the time. At Perth Sheriff Court, he was sentenced to 250 hours of unpaid work and received a two-year driving ban. Prosecutor Rebecca Kynaston described how northbound motorists near the House of Bruar shopping complex witnessed McCormack driving southward on the wrong side of the road. Drivers managed to swerve onto the verge to avoid him, but another vehicle with a family was struck. The lorry hit the side of the car, causing significant damage. Police eventually intercepted the lorry further down the road after the prolonged dangerous driving. McCormack, aged 46 from Kilmarnock, pleaded guilty to dangerous driving, failing to stop after an accident, and driving a vehicle in an unsafe condition. His defence solicitor stated McCormack had no recollection of the incident beyond remembering a sneezing episode. Sheriff Lindsay Foulis noted that five vehicles had to take avoiding action and highlighted the potential catastrophic consequences of driving on the opposite carriageway of a main trunk road.

Foreign Affairs Secretary Perfecto Yasay is set to address the South China Sea dispute at the upcoming two-day Asia-Europe summit, which begins on Friday and will be attended by China's Premier Li Keqiang. This follows a UN-backed tribunal's recent ruling that rejected China's maritime claims, which Beijing has firmly declared it will disregard. The Asia-Europe Meeting Summit in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, will bring together 53 leaders from Asia and Europe, marking the first major diplomatic gathering since the July 12 tribunal decision. For the Philippines, this summit represents President Rodrigo Duterte's international debut, with Yasay expected to articulate the country's peaceful and rules-based approach to the territorial dispute. Unlike his predecessor, Duterte has adopted a more conciliatory stance, suggesting potential resource-sharing with China. While the Philippines initially welcomed the tribunal's ruling as a significant milestone, China maintains that the summit is not an appropriate platform for discussing the issue. The arbitration tribunal, established under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, found that China had violated the Philippines' sovereign rights and caused environmental damage through artificial island construction. Although the ruling is legally binding, the Permanent Court of Arbitration lacks enforcement mechanisms.

Stephen Crabb praised the event as an exceptional showcase of Wales's strengths and positive attributes. He highlighted the remarkably effective collaboration with the Welsh government and First Minister Carwyn Jones, emphasizing their commitment to setting aside political differences. Over 60 world leaders, 4,000 delegates, and 1,500 journalists gathered at Celtic Manor Resort for one of the UK's largest international events. Crabb expressed pride in demonstrating Wales's hospitality, infrastructure, and facilities to the world, believing the summit would enhance Wales's global profile and attract future investment. The accompanying UK Investment Summit in November aims to capitalize on these diplomatic connections. US President Barack Obama commended Wales's extraordinary beauty and hospitality, while local traders in Cardiff experienced business challenges due to security measures. First Minister Carwyn Jones celebrated the week's success, highlighting Obama's endorsement and expressing hope for continued momentum. Cardiff council committed to removing city center security barriers by Sunday afternoon. As a diplomatic gesture, world leaders received willow baskets containing Welsh gifts, accompanied by a note from Prime Minister David Cameron encouraging exploration of Wales's offerings.

Google Assistant, previously exclusive to Pixel phones, is now expanding its reach to more Android devices. Similar to Siri on iPhones, the service enables users to interact with apps and ask questions. LG was among the first smartphone manufacturers to incorporate the assistant in its G6 device. The update will be rolled out this week for users running Android 6.0 Marshmallow or 7.0 Nougat. Gummi Hafsteinsson, Google Assistant's product lead, highlighted that hundreds of millions of Android users can now experience the service. Meanwhile, other virtual assistants are also making strides. At the Mobile World Congress, Lenovo Moto announced Alexa's integration into the Moto Z phone through a MotoMod, while Huawei revealed plans to include Alexa on its devices at CES. Google Assistant distinguishes itself by fostering conversational interactions and responding to follow-up queries. Tech analyst Ian Fogg from IHS Technology noted that expanding Assistant aligns with Google's AI-driven strategy, as increased usage enhances the system's machine learning capabilities. Initially, the service will be available to English-speaking users in the United States, with subsequent rollouts in Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom, followed by support for additional languages.

The election commission (Inec) anticipated announcing the winner on Monday. The UN commended the election despite technical challenges, protests, and Boko Haram-related violence. Voting extended to a second day in some Nigerian regions due to issues with new electronic card readers. President Jonathan was among those unable to vote using the technology, which was introduced to prevent fraud. His Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), previously opposed to card readers, labeled the situation a "huge national embarrassment". Inec chair Attahiru Jega emphasized that only a small percentage of the 150,000 nationwide card readers had malfunctioned. The election was delayed by six weeks because of the Boko Haram insurgency. Militants attacked polling stations in north-eastern states, with Bauchi State imposing a curfew after clashes between security forces and the group. UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon praised Nigerian voters' "determination and resilience" despite reported attacks, describing the voting as "largely peaceful and orderly". Ecowas echoed these sentiments, urging Nigerians to accept the results. Tension emerged in Rivers State, where thousands protested alleged opposition worker killings and voting irregularities. Inec expressed concern about the complaints, noting that one of their offices was burned during the unrest. Election results were expected to emerge Sunday night, with no clear indication of which party was leading. While the PDP has dominated Nigerian politics since 1999, Gen Buhari's All Progressives Congress presented a significant challenge. Voters were also electing representatives to the house and senate.

Geoffrey Stewart, 74, from Dumfries, was among three elderly men who became lost in the Southern Uplands on Tuesday. He passed away late Wednesday night at Dumfries and Galloway Royal Infirmary. George Crosbie, 73, also from Dumfries, died earlier that day. Bobby Thomson, 64, remains hospitalized. Mr. Stewart's family expressed their love and thoughts to those involved, extending sincere gratitude to the rescue services and hospital staff. The men had failed to return from a walk in the Durisdeer hills, prompting a massive search effort. Sixteen Moffat Mountain Rescue team members and two search dogs initially scanned the area until early Wednesday, but the search was suspended due to harsh weather conditions. When operations resumed at 08:30, over 50 people participated, including neighboring rescue teams and a Coastguard helicopter. The men were located that afternoon and airlifted to hospital. Police reported that Mr. Crosbie died shortly after arrival, with his companions treated for hypothermia. Moffat MRT leader Colin Golphin noted the rapidly deteriorating weather conditions and offered condolences to the families. The walkers, experienced and familiar with the Lowther Hills area, were regular visitors to the region.

Unemployment decreased to 1.69 million between January and March, a slight drop of 2,000 from the previous quarter. The Office for National Statistics (ONS) reported that the jobless rate remained steady at 5.1%. Employment rose to 31.58 million, with an increase of 44,000 from the previous quarter, pushing the employment rate to a record high of 74.2%. Job vacancies declined by 18,000 to 745,000, marking the first reduction in nearly a year. ONS senior statistician David Freeman noted that while the employment rate hit another record, the increase was modest, suggesting a potential cooling of the jobs market. Average earnings, including bonuses, grew by 2% year-on-year, up from 1.9% in the previous period, with the ONS attributing the rise partly to bonus timing. Excluding bonuses, earnings increased by 2.1% year-on-year in the three months to March. Jobless benefit claims dropped by 2,400 in April to 737,800, though revised data showed a significant increase of 14,700 between February and March. Work and Pensions Secretary Stephen Crabb celebrated the record-breaking figures, highlighting the highest employment rate in a decade. However, economists expressed caution, with David Kern from the British Chambers of Commerce noting signs of economic softening, and Paul Hollingsworth from Capital Economics suggesting the jobs recovery was losing momentum. Martin Beck from the EY Item Club acknowledged that the rapid unemployment drops of 2015 were unlikely to continue indefinitely.

Taibu, 32, had represented Zimbabwe in 28 Test matches and 150 one-day internationals before retiring in 2012. "I initially thought it was a prank when he introduced himself," Hightown publicity officer Nick Gordon stated. "After further discussion and obtaining references from Zimbabwe cricket professionals, we've maintained contact. It's a significant achievement for us." The wicketkeeper-batsman might make his debut for the Second Division team when they face Alder on 24 April. Gordon told BBC Radio Merseyside that Taibu reached out to the club after they advertised for an overseas player for the summer. "Signing a player like Tatenda is extraordinary for Hightown St Mary's," Gordon said. "I was genuinely stunned. We sought young players, but he clarified that he was a retired Test cricketer." Gordon added, "This individual has performed at an exceptional cricket standard, and we're willing to take a chance. Even if he hasn't played since 2012, he'll likely exceed our summer requirements." The signing of the former international, who scored 1546 runs in 28 Test matches, surprised both Hightown's players and rival teams. "Initially, there was complete disbelief," Gordon explained. "The players thought it was a joke, but gradually, excitement has built. Such opportunities are rare at the club level." He noted the buzz on social media and the anticipation of players facing an international Test captain. "These are working professionals who will now compete against a distinguished cricketer. It's tremendously beneficial for local cricket."

The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, meaning "fuel shortage in a film", became France's top Twitter trend on Tuesday, generating over 5,000 tweets. A strike against new labour laws is disrupting all eight of France's oil refineries. Approximately 20% of petrol stations are either empty or critically low on supplies. Social media users creatively referenced films like Total Recall, while also playing on the Total oil company name. Users humorously renamed movies to reflect the fuel crisis: Pulp Fiction became Pump Friction, The Full Monty transformed into The Fuel Monty, and Mad Max: Fury Road was reimagined as Mad Max: Bicycle Lane. Vin Diesel's films received particular attention, with variations like Last and Furious, Pas Fast Mais Furious, Immobile and Furious, and Fuel Furious. Other movie titles were similarly adapted, such as 8 Mile becoming 0 Mile and 8 Miles a Pied. Stanley Kubrick's films also inspired wordplay, with Full Metal Jacket becoming Fuel Metal Jacket. Users even incorporated jerrycan references, creating titles like Tom and Jerrycan, Jerrycan Beauty, and Catch Me If You Jerrycan. Drive was playfully renamed Walk and Drive Pas, reflecting the current transportation challenges.

Immigration Minister Peter Dutton revealed the interception of a 17-year-old at Sydney airport two weeks ago, highlighting a "growing threat" from Australians seeking to join terrorist groups like Islamic State (IS). Special anti-terror teams deployed at Australia's eight international airports in August have been actively monitoring potential travelers. The teenager, who was attempting to reach the Middle East conflict zone, was returned to his parents' custody pending further investigation. This incident followed the earlier detention of two Sydney brothers, aged 16 and 17, at the same airport for similar suspicions. Despite parental concerns, these students were permitted to continue their education at a prominent Sydney high school. Australian anti-terrorism units have engaged with 85,000 individuals at airports nationwide since August. The country estimates approximately 90 citizens have traveled to Iraq or Syria to fight with IS, with 20 already killed in the conflict. Unconfirmed reports suggest Melbourne teenager Jake Bilardi conducted a suicide attack in Syria after joining IS. His father, John Bilardi, described his son as a "loner" with a "death wish" whom IS treated as a "trophy" and publicly celebrated for recruitment. Under Australian law, it is a criminal offense for citizens to enter IS-controlled cities like Mosul and Raqqa without legitimate reasons, with potential imprisonment of up to 10 years.

The amnesty covers offenses committed during the political unrest following Mr Thaksin's overthrow by a military coup. The lower house approved the contentious bill in the early morning hours of Friday, with the bill now proceeding to the Senate. The Democrat Party warned that the bill's passage would spark street demonstrations. While the party abstained from voting, the bill was approved by 310 votes to zero. According to the BBC's South East Asia correspondent, the bill's passage through the Senate is less predictable, as half its members are appointed, but it could potentially occur as early as next week, likely triggering further protests. Supporters argue the bill will help resolve the political divisions stemming from the 2006 coup, which included significant events like the airport occupation in 2008 and deadly street protests in 2010 that resulted in approximately 90 civilian deaths. However, human rights organizations criticize the amnesty, arguing it would shield perpetrators from accountability. The opposition believes the bill is strategically designed to facilitate Mr Thaksin's return from exile without facing imprisonment. Initially targeting ordinary protesters, the bill was unexpectedly expanded to include individuals investigated by post-coup agencies. Despite being ousted, Thaksin remains popular among rural voters, with parties aligned to him winning subsequent elections. His sister Yingluck currently serves as prime minister. The Democrat Party has pledged to continue fighting the legislation through street protests and potential Constitutional Court challenges. On the day of the debate, thousands gathered to protest against the bill.

Forest Enterprise Scotland plans to plant acorns around Loch Trool and the Cree Valley in the coming years, with the aim of growing approximately 600,000 young trees to establish a "large and vibrant habitat". Environment forester Gareth Ventress explained that upon recognizing a "bumper crop" of acorns, they immediately began planning their collection, seeking assistance from staff across Scotland to gather acorns from native oak woods on the national forest estate. The Cree Valley Community Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust, and Moffat Community Woodlands also contributed to the collection effort to support native woodland expansion in southern Scotland. By combining acorns from Galloway Forest Park, they aim to enhance genetic diversity, creating woodlands that are more resilient to potential pests and diseases in the future. The collection process involves laying large felt nets on the forest floor to facilitate easier gathering and prevent contamination. After collection, the acorns are sorted and stored, with plans to germinate and grow them over the next three to four years. During this period, many seeds will be graded out and deemed infertile. The anticipated 600,000 saplings are expected to establish new oak woods and enrich woodland habitats throughout the Galloway Forest Park.

Mark Carney highlighted the potential for green project financing in emerging markets to enhance financial stability during a speech in Berlin. He advocated for Germany to leverage its 2017 G20 presidency to drive progress. While capital theoretically should move from advanced to emerging economies due to higher returns, Carney noted the opposite trend has occurred, causing bond yield reductions in developed markets. He emphasized that sporadic capital flows to emerging economies have been destabilizing. Green finance, he argued, presents a significant opportunity to promote financial stability by directing capital towards long-term projects in carbon-intensive countries. Carney predicted green bond issuance could double from $42bn in 2015, though they currently represent just 1% of global financial institutional holdings. He described this emerging asset class as a pathway to advancing a low-carbon future while stimulating global investment and growth. Carney also cautioned about the timing challenge of climate change response, suggesting that by the time economic incentives become clear, it might be too late to act effectively. He warned that an overly rapid transition to a low-carbon economy could potentially disrupt financial stability. Additionally, he urged companies to transparently disclose climate change-related financial risks to their business models, reiterating his previous concerns about potential unrecoverable fossil fuel reserves as governments seek to limit global warming.

Gene Palmer is the second prison employee arrested in connection with the jail break. Joyce Mitchell has already been charged with assisting the escape. Richard Matt and David Sweat, both convicted murderers, used power tools to break out of Clinton Correctional Facility. An extensive search continues to locate the fugitives. Mr. Palmer was released on bail after a court appearance facing charges of introducing contraband into prison, tampering with evidence, and official misconduct. His attorney, Andrew Brockway, acknowledged his client delivered meat but claimed he was unaware it contained tools or that the prisoners intended to escape. "He did pass the hamburger meat. He shouldn't have done it. He apologised for it,'' Mr. Brockway stated, noting his client plans to plead not guilty. District Attorney Andrew Wylie revealed that Ms. Mitchell had hidden hacksaw blades and other tools inside the meat, which Mr. Palmer then delivered to Matt and Sweat in a section of the jail where prisoners prepare their own food. Law enforcement is currently focusing their search on a 75 sq mi area in northern New York state. Evidence suggests the men stayed at a hunting cabin near the prison, and authorities believe they may be armed due to the region's abundance of weapons. "They are extremely dangerous, they're cunning," said New York State Police Major Charles Guess. "Why wouldn't they try to arm themselves immediately upon escape?''

The party's election manifesto indicated that a funding floor would only be implemented following a referendum. The St David's Day Agreement had previously suggested the vote would be an "expectation", with Labour Welsh ministers opposing a referendum before a funding deal. Labour criticized the Conservatives for attempting to pressure them. The manifesto outlined the Conservatives' plan to introduce a 'funding floor' to safeguard Welsh relative funding and provide planning certainty, contingent on calling a referendum on Income Tax powers in the next Parliament. A Welsh Conservative spokeswoman clarified that their commitment to a funding floor is firm, with work already progressing at the Treasury and Wales Office. She emphasized that the funding floor is not dependent on an income tax referendum, and their expectation is for the Welsh Assembly to hold a referendum on tax-raising powers early in the next Parliament. Chancellor George Osborne previously stated the funding floor would be between £113 and £116 per head for every £100 spent in England, aligning with economist Gerry Holtham's recommendation. Labour supports introducing a funding floor but has not specified a precise figure. First Minister Carwyn Jones criticized the Conservative approach, arguing it could cost Wales up to £300m annually. The Liberal Democrats proposed an independent review of funding arrangements, while Plaid Cymru advocated for an additional £1.2bn annual funding to match Scottish spending levels. UKIP suggested scrapping the existing Barnett formula for determining national funding.

Hibs suffered a heavy 10-1 aggregate defeat to Bayern Munich, while City lost 3-1 to Eskilstuna United from Sweden. Signeul told BBC Scotland that it was fantastic for Scottish football to have two teams in the Champions League, emphasizing that their achievements had secured these spots. She highlighted that the Netherlands, who will host Euro 2017 and play Scotland in a friendly, only have one team in the competition. The rankings and previous performances of Glasgow City and the national team were crucial factors, she noted. For Hibs, making their knockout stage debut, it was a challenging experience against Bayern Munich, a team with 26 full-time professional players from various national squads, including the Olympic golden boot winner. Signeul stressed the importance of this exposure for Hibs players to understand the high level of competition. City, nine-time Scottish champions, reached the quarter-finals in 2014 but have struggled in recent years. Signeul commented that while City had chances, Eskilstuna, the Swedish runners-up, were ultimately too strong. Addressing comparisons with the men's team, Signeul argued that women's football results typically follow rankings, unlike the more unpredictable men's game. She also expressed support for Gordon Strachan, believing he continues to have his players' backing despite recent qualification challenges.

A potential future transportation model involves hiring rather than owning vehicles. This week, oBike demonstrated this concept by launching in London, backed by significant venture capital and deploying hundreds of hire bikes across the city's streets. The company plans to expand to thousands of bikes by summer's end, following successful operations in South East Asia. Unlike existing cycle hire schemes, these bikes have no docking stations and can be left anywhere using a rear brake lock. Users locate bikes through a GPS-enabled app, with a £49 refundable deposit and a 50p per half-hour usage fee. More companies are expected to follow suit. oBike claims to complement existing schemes and aims to improve London's air quality and reduce emissions, seeking collaboration with Transport for London and local councils. However, this approach has caused friction, with some councils expressing frustration at the unannounced bike deployments. Hackney Council, while supportive of cycle hire, is concerned about bikes potentially obstructing pavements and roads. Hammersmith & Fulham Council similarly criticized the unannounced arrival of 400 yellow bikes in their borough. Council leader Stephen Cowan emphasized the need for proper consultation. London's Walking and Cycling Commissioner, Will Norman, echoed these sentiments, stressing the importance of working with local authorities to ensure these bike-sharing schemes benefit all Londoners without negatively impacting road users and pedestrians. This situation reflects an ongoing tension between innovative technology companies and city authorities.

Gabon was chosen as the host by the Confederation of African Football's Executive Committee, outperforming Ghana and Algeria. Jean-Felix Mba Nze, a Gabon football official, confidently stated their intention to win the 2017 Nations Cup. Gabon first participated in the tournament in 1970 but only qualified for the finals in 1994. Their most notable performances were quarter-final appearances in 1996 and 2012, when they co-hosted the event with Equatorial Guinea. During the recent Nations Cup in Equatorial Guinea, the Panthers were eliminated early after winning one and losing two group matches. The 2017 tournament will mark the first time Gabon hosts the finals independently. Mba Nze, the federation's secretary general, told BBC Sport that their primary goal is to organize a superior competition compared to 2012, attributing their successful bid to an impressive presentation and significant infrastructure improvements in stadiums, hospitals, and media facilities. They will utilize two stadiums from the 2012 finals in Libreville and Franceville, and add two new venues in Port Gentil and Oyem, both expected to be completed by August 2016. The selection was met with criticism from Algeria and Ghana, with Algerian media describing it as a 'sporting and political defeat' and the Ghanaian bid requesting more transparency. The Confederation of African Football defended its decision by referencing its previous approach of not publicly releasing voting results.

Music festival enthusiasts typically spend £581 annually, frequently choosing VIP packages and enhanced camping arrangements. Predominantly male, these "superfans" are more inclined to purchase music on CDs or through digital downloads. A survey of 504 UK residents who attended at least one festival in the past year revealed that these dedicated fans play a crucial role in promoting music events, often recommending performances to their social circles. Comprising 28% of festival attendees, over half are willing to go to events alone. They spend an average of £45 more per event compared to casual fans, though their commitment isn't absolute, with 46% feeling festivals are becoming overly commercialized. The UK hosts more than 100 music festivals annually, ranging from major events like Glastonbury to niche gatherings such as the Cambridge Jazz Festival. Music UK reports that 3.7 million people attend these events, supporting approximately 39,000 full-time jobs. Despite the sector's vibrancy, the industry faces challenges including slim profit margins and market saturation. Some festivals have struggled, with numerous events cancelling in recent years due to various factors. However, the latest research offers optimism, with 88% of respondents planning to attend festivals again, and more than half intending to increase their participation. Industry leaders remain hopeful about the sector's resilience and ability to deliver compelling experiences for music fans.

Over the weekend, Cromer witnessed 37 recorded crimes, including the rape of a teenager, with residents attributing the incidents to a group of travellers. Suffolk Constabulary reported warning Norfolk Police about the group prior to its arrival on Friday. Norfolk acknowledged being informed and stated it was reviewing its response. Suffolk officers explained they had alerted their Norfolk counterparts after the group was issued a local authority notice to leave Lowestoft on Friday afternoon, following multiple disturbance incidents. Norfolk confirmed receiving the information but claimed there was "no intelligence to suggest where the group was heading". A late-teen woman was raped at a bus stop near the seafront on Friday, with Norfolk Police suggesting a potential link to the town's disorder. One man was arrested and released under investigation for the rape, with no additional arrests made. A taxi driver told a BBC reporter that "travellers are rampaging the town", and The Wellington pub staff closed after 30 travellers became "rowdy". Local business owners reported intimidating behavior, including Lee Sale from an ice cream shop and Ayrun Nessa from Masala Twist restaurant, who described confrontational encounters. Cromer's Safer Neighbourhood Team is hosting police surgeries to address community concerns. Approximately 25 travellers' caravans arrived at the Runton Road cliff-top car park on Friday and have since departed.

An A320 pilot reported a white quadcopter drone rapidly passing by the aircraft while flying south of Brookmans Park last August. The UK Airprox Board report noted that no avoiding action was possible due to the extremely limited time available, concluding that a collision was narrowly avoided primarily by chance. Air traffic control reported the pilot stating that something had just passed over him at approximately 18:45 BST on 15 August 2016 while flying north of Potters Bar. The pilot described the object as red and white, with red and blue stripes on two rotor arms, measuring less than a metre in size. Drone operators are legally required to comply with Air Navigation Order (ANO) 2016 articles, which mandate that operators must only fly a drone when reasonably certain of safe operation and must not recklessly endanger any person or property. Additionally, they must maintain direct, unaided visual contact sufficient to monitor the aircraft's flight path relative to other aircraft. Airprox board members determined that the drone was operated at an altitude beyond direct unaided line-of-sight, which is not permitted without explicit Civil Aviation Authority permission, effectively placing it in conflict with the A320. Despite the investigation, the drone operator could not be identified.

A comprehensive study of workplace personnel revealed that 25% of new fathers did not take any paternity leave whatsoever. Less than 10% utilized more than their mandatory two-week allocation. The research conducted by the Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM) highlighted deeply rooted employer attitudes and financial concerns as primary obstacles for fathers. While the government announced plans to enable parental leave sharing, with implementation scheduled for April 2015, the ILM warned that systemic cultural barriers could undermine these efforts. The report emphasized persistent organizational expectations that women would be primarily responsible for extended workplace absences. Notably, financial constraints significantly impacted leave decisions, with only 9% of surveyed fathers receiving full pay beyond two weeks. Trade union representatives stressed that economic factors prevented many fathers from taking time off, as employers rarely supplement statutory pay. Current regulations permit one or two weeks of paid paternity leave, with additional provisions if mothers return to work. Government initiatives aim to introduce greater flexibility, allowing parents to exchange and share leave. Officials expressed hope that these changes would promote a cultural transformation, enabling fathers to be more involved in early childcare while helping businesses retain talented female employees and maintain workforce productivity.

Similar to last year's parade, only the Orangemen and their 13 designated bands are permitted to march past St Patrick's Church on Donegall Street in north Belfast, restricted to a single drum beat. This year, all music must cease 43 metres before the church to ensure no sound reaches within its vicinity. The planned residents' protest has also been limited to a maximum of 50 people at two specific locations. The Orange Order expressed strong opposition to the ruling, describing the commission as a "mouthpiece for republican propaganda" that dictates parade terms. They criticized the new criteria of banning music within "earshot" of an unused place of worship as mischievous and designed to censor Protestant heritage. North Belfast MP Nigel Dodds of the DUP condemned the determination as a "bureaucratic monstrosity" that capitulates to republican residents. He highlighted the commission's consideration of potentially banning music outside Clifton Street Orange hall. In contrast, SDLP assembly member Alban Maginness welcomed the decision, describing it as sensible and expressing hope that it would set a constructive tone for the marching season. He emphasized that the parishioners and local residents have consistently sought respectful treatment.

The 34-year-old midfielder has recently concluded his latest stint in the Indian Super League with Atletico Kolkata. "Having previously returned three times, I understand the attraction and motivation for coming back," McFadden said, confirming that Well have extended an offer. "And I know Pearo feels exactly the same way." Pearson initially started his career at Fir Park and, following periods with Celtic, Derby County, Bristol City, and Karela Blasters, rejoined Well for a season in 2015. He is currently a free agent after helping Kolkata secure fourth place in the league and ultimately winning the title through a play-off victory against his former club, Karela. "We've discussed terms with him and presented an offer, now we're awaiting his response," McFadden noted, highlighting Motherwell's tradition of welcoming back former players. "Pearo would be an excellent addition both on and off the field here. We would love to have him return, so hopefully he makes the right decision." McFadden acknowledged that Pearson has some considerations before making his choice, but emphasized he would be warmly welcomed. Motherwell have recently strengthened their squad by signing winger Elliot Frear from Forest Green and securing loans for Reading defender Zak Jules and Everton goalkeeper Russell Griffiths. However, they remain open to further recruitment before the transfer window closes. "We're still exploring possibilities," McFadden added, "but we're waiting on responses from potential targets."

Kevin Mcleod's body was discovered in Wick harbour during February 1997. Although the 24-year-old's death was initially deemed accidental, his family contended that bodily injuries suggested murder. Following communication between his family and chief constable Phil Gormley, a comprehensive assessment of "all known information" was conducted. Police reported that the review involved tracing and interviewing previously unheard witnesses present in Wick the night of Mr Mcleod's death. His mother, June, previously stated to BBC Scotland that if the assessment yielded no new insights, the family would persist in seeking a fresh investigation. A parallel assessment was commissioned by the chief constable to examine the police's handling of the Mcleod family's complaints regarding the death investigation since 1997. Det Ch Supt Gareth Blair, Police Scotland's major crime head, explained the assessment recognized the continued impact on Mr Mcleod's parents and their desire for conclusive answers. He emphasized that this was not a full reinvestigation but a careful analysis of accumulated information since 1997, involving specialist officers tracing and interviewing previously uncontacted individuals. After informing Mr Mcleod's parents of the assessment's conclusion, Blair stated no criminality evidence was found, and the death remains unexplained, resulting in no basis for a full reinvestigation. Police Scotland continues to invite witnesses with information about Kevin's death to come forward, and the chief constable has requested a professional standards review of the family's historical complaints.

Matthew Eteson is currently facing trial at Preston Crown Court, charged with gross negligence manslaughter in connection with the deaths of Kelly Webster, 36, and Lauren Thornton, who died while sleeping on a boat at Windermere in April 2013. Mr Eteson, 42, from Hale in Greater Manchester, pleads not guilty to the charge. The family had traveled to the Lake District for an Easter bank holiday weekend birthday celebration. Prosecutor Graham Reeds QC alleged that Mr Eteson removed the generator from the deck and used it to power a 1kW fan heater to warm the sleeping area. The court was informed that no warning was issued about toxic gas accumulation because carbon monoxide sensors had been previously disabled. Mr Reeds stated that the mother and daughter, both from Leyland, were discovered deceased in their sleeping positions on the second-hand Bayliner 285 motor cruiser Arniston, with fatal carbon monoxide levels in their bodies. Mr Eteson, who was sleeping in a separate compartment further from the generator, also experienced carbon monoxide poisoning but awakened to find the bodies. Testimony revealed that Mr Eteson, a qualified gas fitter, had made modifications to the generator and its exhaust, which experts subsequently characterized as "dangerous". Kelly Webster's mother, Nia Webster, had previously inquired about carbon monoxide sensors, to which Mr Eteson responded that they were non-functional and his partner would unplug a portable detector while cooking. The trial is ongoing.

NHS Blood and Transplant highlighted the critical importance of O negative blood, which comprises 12% of transfers despite only 7% of UK residents having this blood type. The organisation emphasized the significance of B negative blood for ethnic minority groups, who are more susceptible to conditions like sickle cell anaemia and thalassemia. Although B negative represents just 2% of Britain's population, hospitals have used 6% more of this blood type compared to the previous year. B negative blood is particularly versatile, suitable for both B negative and B positive patients. Donna Batty, donor relations manager, urged donors to come forward in the next few days, noting that stocks for these vulnerable groups were lower than desired. She also requested donors with upcoming appointments to maintain their commitments. Jon Latham, assistant director of marketing, stressed the importance of expanding their donor database, particularly seeking first-time donors. Currently, only 4% of the UK population donates blood. The NHSBT encourages individuals unsure of their blood type to donate and learn their type, and interested persons can contact the organisation at 0300 123 23 23.

Dr Stephen Farry, the Employment and Learning minister, has decided to eliminate a special premium payment of £1.1m that compensated for the institution's small scale and specialist status. With fewer than 1,000 students and an annual income of £4.7m, the college faces significant challenges. Protesters argue that removing the small institution premium, combined with general DEL funding cuts, would result in a 31% budget reduction. However, an additional £32m for the DEL, revealed in the recent budget, somewhat improves the situation. The college now anticipates a 26.5% budget cut, which Prof Peter Finn still considers extremely challenging. He accuses Farry of making an opportunistic decision to force the college to accept one of his proposed solutions for streamlining teacher training in Northern Ireland. None of the four options preserve St Mary's current autonomy. While determined to maintain its character and Catholic ethos, Prof Finn supports "deep sharing" between teacher training institutions, potentially involving cross-campus student teaching. He strongly disputes the rationale for removing the small scale and specialist premia, noting that while similar institutions in England lost these payments, they were permitted higher tuition fees and student intake flexibility, which St Mary's was not. Stranmillis University College faces comparable issues and has been negotiating a merger with Queen's University since 2008, though the process remains unapproved and opposed.

The investment is supported by nearly £15m from the Welsh government, with production set to commence in late 2018. Economy Minister Edwina Hart emphasized that the deal would "safeguard more than 750 skilled Welsh jobs for many years". She highlighted the strategic effort to secure a portion of this investment for Wales, praising Ford's decision to manufacture its innovative engine in the region as a testament to the local management team and workforce's quality and loyalty. The Bridgend plant, operational since 1980, has successfully competed for investments totaling over £2.8bn. Ford noted that its presence supports approximately 10,000 jobs in south Wales, with 1,860 directly employed at the facility. Technicians from Essex and Germany collaborated on designing a new fuel-efficient engine range. A previous communication from Ford indicated that winning the investment would require workplace condition modifications to enhance competitiveness. Welsh Conservative shadow economy minister William Graham viewed the announcement as evidence of the UK government's economic recovery efforts. The development is particularly promising for Bridgend workers, as the new production begins in 2018, coinciding with the conclusion of Jaguar Land Rover engine manufacturing. This secures hundreds of potentially vulnerable jobs, following the earlier dismissal of 200 fixed contract workers after ending Volvo engine production. However, concerns persist about potential reduced engine manufacturing capacity and the rationale behind government financial support for a multinational company. The highly competitive automotive industry often necessitates government backing to prevent companies from relocating production.

S4C primarily derives its funding from the licence fee, and UK ministers have initiated a comprehensive review of the BBC. Monmouth MP David Davies highlighted S4C as a "special case" due to its role in promoting the Welsh language. Ministers have indicated that S4C should pursue cost savings similar to those expected of the BBC. Labour expressed concerns that BBC budget cuts could potentially jeopardize S4C, but Culture Secretary John Whittingdale assured MPs of a commitment to the channel in the coming years and planned discussions with its management. During an interview on Rhaglen Dylan Jones, Mr Davies emphasized the government's recognition of S4C's significance beyond being a mere television station, describing it as crucial to the Welsh language's future. He also suggested the possibility of the Welsh Affairs Committee, which he leads, conducting a broadcasting inquiry. S4C has acknowledged experiencing significant financial reductions since 2010 and intends to stress its service's unique cultural and economic value during ministerial discussions. A recently released green paper noted declining audience engagement with indigenous language services, particularly in Wales, and raised concerns about the higher production costs of Welsh-language radio programming compared to English-language content.

The most recent Markit Report on Jobs for Scotland revealed significant increases in both permanent and temporary job placements during April. Temporary staff demand reached its highest point in nearly a decade. However, recruiters warned that this success could be undermined by diminishing candidate availability, as employers encountered difficulties securing the necessary skills. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) emphasized that the incoming government following the 8 June general election must protect access to international workers and invest in domestic jobseekers. The report highlighted continued growth in permanent appointments for the third consecutive month, with the fastest expansion in 21 months - a trend contrasting with the broader UK slowdown. Temporary placements saw a sharp increase, the steepest since August 2014. Worker availability continued to decline, with the most significant drop in permanent staff availability in nine months and the quickest reduction in temporary candidates in nearly two years. Sectors experiencing the highest permanent staff demand included IT and computing, nursing/medical/care, and hotel and catering, while nursing/medical/care, IT and computing, and engineering and construction led temporary staff growth. Average salaries for permanent and temporary roles in Scotland rose significantly, with temporary pay increasing at its fastest rate in a year. REC chief executive Kevin Green noted the Scottish jobs market's resilience, highlighting the high demand for temporary staff amid Brexit uncertainty and the positive trend in starting salaries, while cautioning about the potential risks posed by declining candidate availability.

Envoy Sigrid Kaag commented as Syria appeared to miss a deadline for removing its chemical weapons arsenal. The international agreement to eliminate these weapons was established last year following a deadly sarin rocket attack near Damascus. The multinational mission, supervised by the UN Security Council and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), aims to destroy Syria's chemical weapons by 30 June. Although Damascus had previously committed to completing the stockpile removal by 27 April, significant progress has been made. Kaag noted that the majority of chemical weapons materials have been removed but not yet destroyed, which still counts towards the June deadline. She expressed concern about reports of Syrian forces potentially using chlorine gas, a substance not originally included in the disarmament deal. According to the OPCW, most of Syria's chemical weapons exist as separate materials that become toxic when combined. Kaag emphasized that the facilities capable of producing and launching chemical weapons have been destroyed, and the current chemical weapons programme, as declared to the OPCW under the Chemical Weapons Convention, no longer exists. Damascus has denied using chlorine gas as a weapon, and the agreement is widely seen as having prevented US military intervention.

Seattle Reign's Kim Little claimed the BBC World Service award after topping a supporters' poll, becoming the second recipient of the honor. She outperformed a competitive shortlist including Gaelle Enganamouit, Amandine Henry, Carli Lloyd, and Becky Sauerbrunn. Expressing surprise and humility, the 25-year-old emphasized her hope for women's football's continued progress. Little received the award at her club's training ground, with BBC World Service English Controller Mary Hockaday praising her exceptional talent. In 2015, Little was Seattle's top scorer and second-highest in the National Women's Soccer League, netting 10 goals and helping her team lead the league. She also played on loan at Melbourne City that year. A five-time title winner with Arsenal Ladies and a former Hibernian player, Little has represented Scotland 115 times, scoring 46 goals. Her achievements include helping Great Britain reach the quarter-finals at the 2012 London Olympics and winning individual accolades such as the FA's Women's Player of the Year in 2010 and the inaugural PFA Women's Players' Player of the Year in 2013. Scotland coach Anna Signeul lauded Little as a complete player with exceptional skills, describing her as a role model who sets an extraordinary standard both on and off the pitch.

Fraser, ranked 90th globally, scored nine birdies to complete an impressive eight under par 63, establishing a three-shot lead over the competition. Several top 10 male golfers withdrew from Rio 2016 due to Zika virus concerns. Britain's Justin Rose, part of a group at four under par, achieved the first Olympic hole-in-one on the fourth hole. Rose described the moment as special, noting the unique achievement of being the first to accomplish this feat. Henrik Stenson, the recent Open champion, is tied for second with Canada's Graham Delaet at five under par. Rose shares fourth place with Thomas Pieters from Belgium, France's Gregory Bourdy, Germany's Alex Cejka, and Spain's Rafael Cabrera Bello. Danny Willett, who won the Masters earlier in the year, finished level par with a 71. The second round will commence on Friday at 11:30 BST, with no halfway cut due to the limited 60-player field. Previously, Rory McIlroy had expressed disinterest in the Olympic golf competition, preferring other Olympic sports.

On 30 January 1915, England and Scotland faced off in a charity match orchestrated by former England international Edgar Mobbs, aimed at recruiting sportsmen to his World War One battalion. A commemorative match is set for 24 January 2015 at Olney Rugby Club, featuring players from the East Midlands region against The 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, with Olney Ladies challenging the Army Women's XV. Edgar Mobbs, born in Northampton in 1882, began his rugby career in Olney and became Northampton Rugby Football Club's captain in 1907. Selected for England in 1909, he scored a try on his debut against Australia and earned seven caps. During the war, he progressed from private to battalion commander, fighting in Loos, Somme, Arras, and Messines. Mentioned in Despatches twice and awarded the Distinguished Service Order, he tragically died charging a German machine gun during the Battle of Passchendaele on 31 July 1917. Despite retiring from rugby in 1913 and being initially refused an officer's commission due to his age, Mobbs enlisted as a private and became a powerful recruitment advocate. He reportedly inspired over 200 men to join, with the 1915 international match helping recruit hundreds to the Sportsman's Battalion, which formed a significant part of the 7th Northamptonshire Regiment. Sixteen Olney players who died during the war were among these recruits. Mobbs's family, including his great-nephew Edgar, will attend the commemorative event. The match will raise funds for the Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association, honoring Mobbs's legacy as both a sporting and war hero.

A new charity will take over management of the National Heritage Collection, encompassing sites like Stonehenge and Dover Castle. Currently receiving £22m in annual government funding, the organization aims to become financially independent. While the charity will retain the name English Heritage, government powers such as building listing will remain state-funded. The new body, provisionally called the National Heritage Protection Service, will also provide planning advice. The 420 sites in the collection, including Kenwood House and Charles Darwin's home, will stay in public ownership. Government funding will be gradually reduced from 2015, enabling the charity to generate income through commercial activities and philanthropic support. An £80m government investment will help establish the charity, ensuring full operational status by March 2015. The agency described these planned changes as an "excellent outcome," emphasizing the transition from 100 years of state heritage protection to a new model for future preservation. This announcement coincides with the government's declaration of potential 5% funding cuts for museums and arts sectors in the 2015-2016 Spending Review.

Christopher Kelly, a 40-year-old man, fatally strangled his friend Dorothy Beattie, 51, at her Dunoon residence in Argyll and Bute on May 22nd. The Glasgow High Court learned that Kelly attacked her following an alleged disparaging comment about his children. Initially charged with murder, Kelly pleaded guilty to culpable homicide after confessing to a GP. Previously a support worker for Ms Beattie, who suffered from multiple medical conditions including seizures, the pair had developed a friendship and frequently socialized together. Kelly assaulted her at her home after she reportedly made derogatory remarks about his children. He strangled Ms Beattie and left the flat, later returning to find her dead, sitting with her body before moving her to the bed and then fleeing. Kelly subsequently traveled to Edinburgh, using Ms Beattie's bank card to steal £300 from her account. The victim's daughter discovered her body on May 25th after failing to make contact. Kelly reportedly slept rough in Edinburgh until May 28th, when he visited a GP surgery and admitted to killing Ms Beattie. During his confession, he described blacking out during the incident and being unaware until realizing she was dead. Police were informed, and Kelly described the preceding days as "torture". The court noted Ms Beattie's injuries involved significant force. Judge Lord Bannatyne indicated the jail term would have been seven years without Kelly's guilty plea, describing the case as tragically. Kelly mouthed "sorry" to the victim's daughters as he was led to the cells in handcuffs.

A train journey from Penzance to Exeter ended in a collision on platform six shortly after 15:30 BST on 3 April. The Rail Accident Investigation Branch's preliminary findings revealed that the signaller believed both trains could occupy the platform simultaneously. Approximately 35 people sustained injuries. The report explained that permissive working, which allows trains to share a platform, was standard practice for platform six. The signaller, observing the train's rear from the signal box, misjudged the available space. One train had been redirected to platform six due to maintenance-related lift closures on other platforms. As the moving train approached Plymouth, it accelerated to around 21 mph while navigating a tight left-hand curve. The driver suddenly noticed the stationary train's proximity to the platform's west end, which surprised him. Realizing a collision was inevitable, he applied the emergency brake approximately three seconds before impact, which occurred at roughly 15 mph. Many passengers, who were standing in preparation to disembark, were violently thrown against the train's interior fixtures and onto the floor.

The 71-year-old secured 60.75% of the vote, with his closest challenger Kizza Besigye receiving 35%, according to the election commission. Museveni's supporters argued that opponents failed to offer meaningful progress. Besigye, confined to house arrest, denounced the results as a "sham" and urged the international community to reject them, declaring it the most fraudulent electoral process in Uganda's history. EU observers criticized the poll, highlighting the governing party's creation of an "intimidating atmosphere" and opposition claims of vote rigging. While praising Ugandans' voting determination, EU Chief Observer Eduard Kukan noted that the National Resistance Movement's political dominance undermined campaign fairness. The election was characterized by sporadic violence and electoral fraud allegations, with social media and messaging platforms blocked. Besigye was placed under house arrest on Friday, allegedly to prevent him from independently announcing results, which police claimed would violate electoral laws. This marks his fourth presidential challenge against Museveni, with whom he was once allied during their guerrilla fighting days. Museveni, who took power in 1986 and is credited with restoring national stability, faces criticism for increasingly authoritarian tendencies. Another challenger, former Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi, was reportedly also under house arrest.

The retailer asserts that the Chippenham project would generate 1,000 jobs and inject £31m annually into the local economy. Among the five parliamentary candidates, one strongly opposes the development, while three express reservations about the proposed site. Local residents have signed petitions both supporting and challenging the plans. Conservative candidate Michelle Donelan acknowledged the complexity, arguing that the consultation was insufficient for a project set to fundamentally transform the town. The 72,000 sq m regional centre application is still pending Wiltshire Council's review, with candidates sharing their perspectives during a BBC Wiltshire election debate. Labour's Andy Newman endorsed the development, citing expectations of 700 permanent skilled jobs and potential wage increases. In stark contrast, Green party candidate Tina Johnston completely rejected the proposal, questioning the claimed job numbers. Two candidates supported the concept but challenged the location, with UKIP's Julia Reid suggesting a site closer to the motorway would be more appropriate and less disruptive to town centre businesses. Liberal Democrat Duncan Hames welcomed the potential job opportunities but remained uncertain about the specific site's suitability.

The 31-year-old claimed she was refused entry to a black cab and told to "find an immigrant" to drive her. This alleged incident followed her previous apology "on behalf of my country" regarding conditions at the Calais Jungle camp. The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association condemned any abusive behavior. In her Twitter post, she described the driver telling her to "find an immigrant to drive you, you stupid tart" when she attempted to enter the cab with her children. She reflected that the interaction provided her with a glimpse of discrimination, despite her privileged life. Some social media users questioned her account, prompting her to defend her story by explaining she was holding her children and couldn't quickly access her phone. The association representing approximately 5,500 London black cab drivers urged Transport for London to investigate the claims. Their general secretary stated they take such allegations seriously and would condemn any driver using disrespectful language. Earlier, Allen had emotionally met Shamsher Sherin, a 13-year-old Afghan boy, on a television program. During their encounter, she apologized for England's perceived historical mistreatment, citing bombing, Taliban involvement, and current migration challenges as examples of harm inflicted on his community.

The transfer fee for the 25-year-old World Cup runner-up remains confidential but is estimated around £8m. Fernandez signs a four-year contract and is expected to be available for Swansea's match against Burnley on Saturday, pending international clearance. Having started four games during Argentina's World Cup campaign, he arrives as a replacement for Chico Flores, who moved to Qatar. The centre-back expressed his excitement about joining Swansea, citing advice from teammates Michu and Jordi Amat. "Playing in the Premier League has always been my dream - it's the best league globally," he stated. Fernandez consulted with Michu, who described Swansea as a family club with a relaxed atmosphere. Manager Garry Monk praised the defender's quality, highlighting his experience with Napoli and Argentina's national team. "He brings top-level pedigree and is at an excellent age for our squad," Monk commented. "He's a good-sized footballer who will suit our playing style and undoubtedly adds quality to the team." Following their 2-1 away victory against Manchester United, Swansea will host Burnley in their first home Premier League match. However, due to his recent World Cup participation, Fernandez's match readiness remains uncertain.

Newly discovered CCTV footage of Charlene Downes, who disappeared at age 14 in Blackpool town centre, has reignited her family's quest for answers. Her mother Karen expressed frustration that the footage was only recently found after years of investigation into the unsolved murder. Lancashire Police acknowledged her concerns. Despite extensive efforts, no one has been convicted in connection with Charlene's death. The footage was released on the anniversary of her 2003 disappearance, marking the force's longest murder investigation. Karen Downes hopes the new images will help detectives make progress and provide closure for her family. The CCTV shows Charlene with her sister Rebecca on Bank Hey Street around 15:25 GMT on 1 November 2003, near the Coral Island arcade, wearing the same clothes she had on when she vanished. Detectives are now exploring potential links between her disappearance and child sexual exploitation in Blackpool, with plans to identify and potentially arrest suspects. Previously, a man was cleared of her murder in 2008 after two trials, with a judge raising significant doubts about the evidence. The Independent Police Complaints Commission later found evidence-gathering errors and disciplined several officers, including one forced to resign in 2011, though this decision was subsequently overturned by a Police Arbitration Tribunal in 2012.

Julia Knight, 56, denies attempting to murder her mother Irene Robson, 81, at Horton Hospital in Banbury during October 2014, but acknowledges administering insulin. At Oxford Crown Court, she testified that her motivation was to prevent her mother's discharge from the hospital. Ms Knight also refutes charges of intentionally causing grievous bodily harm. She explained that her desire was to ensure her mother remained under professional care and not sent home. "I felt terrible knowing I was going to make mum unwell," she said. "It was a stupid, stupid thing to do. If I could go back and change it, I would." She admitted to lying to police during questioning in January. The court learned she had forged an insulin prescription, which she collected from a Sainsbury's store in Banbury. When her defence barrister Simon Mayo QC questioned why she denied injecting her mother to officers, she responded, "I realised it was serious. I was ashamed of what I had done." Prosecutor John Price QC suggested she intended to administer a potentially fatal dose before leaving the hospital. He asked why she injected her mother with a substance that could potentially kill her within minutes, to which she replied, "I never intended my mother to die." Ms Knight also revealed a previous suicide attempt in 2006 involving insulin self-injection. While Ms Robson died in September, the jury was informed that her death was not relevant to the current case. The trial is ongoing.

The Korea Space Launch Vehicle-1 (KSLV-1) successfully launched from the Naro Space Center at 16:00 (07:00 GMT). Science Minister Lee Ju-ho confirmed that the satellite, designed to gather climate information, had reached its intended orbit. This launch occurred shortly after North Korea's controversial satellite deployment, which drew international criticism. The 140-tonne Naro rocket was a collaborative effort with Russia, involving three planned launch attempts. Previous launch efforts in 2009 and 2010 had failed, and this mission had been delayed twice due to technical issues. Officials reported that the rocket reached its target altitude and successfully deployed the satellite 540 seconds after launch. Minister Lee celebrated the achievement, stating that South Korea had taken a significant step toward becoming a space-power nation. The Science and Technology Satellite-2C was expected to establish contact with ground control the following morning, allowing final assessment of the mission's success. While South Korea has previously deployed satellites, this marked its first independent launch from domestic soil. The launch came under heightened scrutiny following North Korea's recent rocket deployment and subsequent announcement of potential nuclear testing plans, which prompted UN sanctions and international concern.

The Hull City owner threatened to quit the Premier League club within 24 hours if the name change bid was rejected, which the Football Association did in April. "When I say something, I mean it," the 75-year-old Egyptian stated on Thursday. He revealed that the club was put up for sale 22 hours after the FA's decision five months ago. Allam confirmed that an appeal was being filed with the Court of Arbitration for Sport against the name change rejection. "We previously stated that the club would be for sale if our attempt to globally promote Hull Tigers as a brand and playing name was blocked," he explained. "Following the FA decision on 9 April, I announced on 10 April, within 22 hours, that Hull City is for sale." When asked what he would do if no buyer was found and the legal appeal failed, Allam declared, "I will give it away. Out means I'm out. Have I ever said anything and gone back on it?" He and his son Ehab, the club's acting chief executive, would remain committed to the club for now. "If the appeal comes first, okay, no harm done. If the sale comes first - sold," he said. He was vague about potential buyer interest and suggested he might stay on if the appeal succeeded. The chairman acknowledged the need for stability for manager Steve Bruce and players, highlighting his transfer window investment, including signing Uruguay striker Abel Hernandez for a reported club record fee of £10m. Hull reached the FA Cup final last season, losing 3-2 to Arsenal after leading 2-0, and finished 16th in their first Premier League season. They currently sit ninth with four points from three matches in the 2014-15 season.

Scot Higgins, a 19-year-old who initiated his football journey at Celtic, later joined Dens Park and featured in four matches for Dundee last season. Alan Power, a 29-year-old former Republic of Ireland Under-21 international, departs Lincoln City in League Two after making over 250 league appearances. Both players have secured two-year contracts with Kilmarnock, with Power's transfer pending final clearance. Higgins expressed his excitement about joining the club, stating it's moving in a positive direction. Manager Lee McCulloch praised Higgins' background from Celtic's renowned academy and highlighted his potential for growth. He noted Higgins' experience at Dundee and believes the young player will continue to develop. Power also shared his enthusiasm, mentioning the club's history and the manager's compelling vision. McCulloch spoke highly of Power, referencing his leadership during Lincoln's FA Cup quarter-final run and emphasizing his aggressive playing style and valuable experience for younger team members. Kilmarnock are set to kick off their league campaign against St Johnstone on 5 August.

England's back row has been severely impacted by injuries, with James Haskell, Sam Jones, Mike Williams, and the versatile Maro Itoje all sidelined. Harrison, 24, played only half an hour in the recent Test match against Australia in Sydney. Jones told BBC Sport that Harrison has diligently worked on his game, with his recent performance against Castres being exceptional, making him currently the preferred open-side flanker. Jones also believes that recalled flanker Tom Wood has a strong chance of selection this autumn. Previously dropped after the Rugby World Cup for "distinctly average" performances, Wood has since improved his work-rate, ball-carrying impact, and is now considered above average. His enhanced lineout skills and breakdown work have excited the coaching staff. Despite selecting six uncapped players in the 33-man squad, Jones has tempered expectations about their chances against the Springboks, stating that debuting against South Africa might not be ideal. England will travel to Portugal for a training camp on Sunday, hoping to avoid the injury-plagued previous camp in Brighton. Jones emphasized their commitment to an injury-free preparation while maintaining the necessary intensity for international rugby.

Adopting the names of government agencies like NASA and the EPA, these accounts are directly challenging the president. Mr. Trump has previously labeled climate change a hoax. The @RogueNASA account describes itself as the "unofficial 'Resistance' team of NASA", clarifying it is "Not an official NASA account" and not managed by government employees. BBC News reached out to the rogue EPA account @ActualEPAFacts, which stated their goal was to ensure "factual information about climate change and scientific research continues to be shared during the Trump administration". Claiming to be three EPA employees, they said they acted after being prevented from conducting interviews about their research. Media reports suggest the Trump administration attempted to restrict communication between certain government agencies and the public. The official EPA Twitter account has remained inactive since January 19, a day before Mr. Trump's inauguration. ActualEPAFacts expressed surprise at their growing follower count of over 90,000 while also feeling vulnerable. Other rogue accounts have similarly gained significant followings, with @RogueNasa attracting over 370,000 followers in just a few days, and @AltNatParkSer amassing more than a million followers with fewer than 300 tweets. Additional alternative accounts exist for the US Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. These accounts use "resistance" language and share a mix of scientific information and critiques of Mr. Trump. Some claim to be disgruntled government workers, with @AltNatParkSer initially stating they were run by National Park Service rangers before later transitioning to activists and journalists. The creation of these accounts was reportedly inspired by climate change tweets from Badlands National Park that were subsequently deleted.

British Marine, representing the leisure, superyacht, and small commercial marine sector, reported that superyacht revenues reached £605m by April 2016. The overall sector's revenues increased by 1.6% to £3.01bn, marking the first time the £3bn threshold has been crossed since 2008-2009. Despite this growth, the report suggested a potential slowdown in 2017 due to Brexit negotiation uncertainties. Following the financial crisis, total revenue had dropped to its lowest point of £2.85bn in 2011-2012 and has been gradually recovering since. The sales increase is attributed to higher revenues from engine and equipment manufacturing and a surge in hire and charter boat sales. Export figures declined slightly by 0.7% to £882m, but British Marine noted that the pound's fall against the dollar and euro has temporarily boosted overseas purchasing power. Marine businesses surveyed expected this benefit to be short-lived. Howard Pridding, British Marine's chief executive, emphasized the industry's resilience, highlighting growing revenue and employment despite post-referendum volatility. The report predicted industry growth would decelerate in 2017 as Brexit negotiations approach. Sunseeker and Princess remain the UK's leading superyacht companies, with the global marine industry ranking fourth in turnover.

Russia, Turkey, and Iran have proposed a plan to establish four "de-escalation zones" in Syria, but the main Syrian opposition group remains skeptical. The High Negotiations Committee (HNC) criticized the deal for lacking proper safeguards and rejected Iran as a guarantor. UN special envoy Staffan de Mistura views the agreement as significant due to the involvement of three influential countries. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported fighter jets bombing rebel positions in Hama, with a rebel commander confirming ongoing fighting. The Russian military announced the "memorandum on the creation of de-escalation areas" following talks in Astana, aiming to halt attacks and facilitate refugee return and humanitarian aid. The zones will be in place for six months, with borders to be finalized by 4 June. Russian Deputy Defence Minister Alexander Fomin stated no bombing raids have occurred in these zones since 1 May, while maintaining strikes against Islamic State militants elsewhere. The US has expressed concerns about Iran's role, and though the Syrian government is not a signatory, it supports the plan. The Astana talks were intended to reinforce a ceasefire originally agreed in December, which has been frequently violated. Syria's conflict, which began in 2011, has resulted in over 300,000 deaths.
