The Chamber of Deputies had previously endorsed the legislation. The Senate vote, which narrowly passed the bill by a margin of six votes, followed an intense 14-hour debate. The law, which extends adoption rights to same-sex couples, encountered strong resistance from the Catholic Church and other religious organizations. Supported by President Cristina Fernandez's centre-left government, the legislation was approved with 33 votes in favor, 27 against, and three abstentions. Outside Congress, as the debate continued into the early morning hours, supporters and opponents held competing demonstrations. Maria Rachid, president of the Argentine Federation of Lesbians, Gays, Bisexuals and Transsexuals, stated, "Nearly every political and social figure has spoken out in favour of marriage equality. We hope the Senate reflects this and that Argentina becomes a more just country for all families." Ines Frank from Argentine Families Argentina argued that opposition was not discriminatory, claiming "the essence of a family is between two people of opposite sexes." Previous gay marriages in Argentina had been annulled by the Supreme Court, creating legal uncertainty. While civil unions between same-sex couples were already legal in Buenos Aires and some provinces, no nationwide regulatory framework existed. Buenos Aires is considered one of Latin America's most gay-friendly cities, having been the first to legalize same-sex unions. Similar legal provisions exist in Uruguay and parts of Brazil and Mexico, with same-sex marriage legal in Mexico City.

The SNP's 54 current MPs are anticipated to receive candidate endorsements. The party will also determine the status of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, who were originally elected as SNP representatives but now serve as independents. Labour's executive is preparing to finalize candidate selection, while other parties have already begun identifying potential challengers. The UK is set to vote on 8 June following Prime Minister Theresa May's snap election announcement, which MPs subsequently approved by an overwhelming margin. McGarry and Thomson were the only Scottish MPs to oppose the election, with SNP members choosing to abstain. The SNP will need to recruit five candidates, including three for seats not won in 2015. Party activists have already expressed interest in securing nominations for Glasgow East and Edinburgh West, the constituencies previously held by McGarry and Thomson. Labour issued a candidate recruitment call via Twitter, inviting party members to apply before Sunday's noon deadline. The Scottish party's executive is meeting to establish selection procedures, with leader Kezia Dugdale confirming their election readiness. Ian Murray, the party's sole Scottish MP, launched his campaign to defend Edinburgh South, followed by Scottish Secretary David Mundell in Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale. Other parties are also declaring candidates, with Tory MSP Douglas Ross challenging SNP deputy leader Angus Robertson in Moray, and former Lib Dem MP Jo Swinson seeking a rematch against John Nicolson in East Dunbartonshire. The Lib Dems are implementing all-female shortlists in several target seats, with some selections potentially being finalized over the weekend.

The charity aims to have 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians displaced by civil war resettled by year-end. Prior to UN talks in Geneva on the crisis, it emphasized that only 1.4% have been assisted so far. Oxfam criticized the UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians by 2020 as insufficient, though Britain maintains its focus on regional aid. The UK's £2.3bn pledge for those affected by Syria's humanitarian crisis positions it as the second-largest bilateral donor globally, after the US. While acknowledging Britain's financial generosity, Oxfam argues that countries with robust economies should bear more refugee responsibility compared to nations like Lebanon and Jordan. The charity calls for the Geneva conference to produce urgent solutions providing safe and legal migration routes. After examining pledges from 28 OECD nations and refugee convention signatories, Oxfam found they promised to accept nearly 130,000 Syrian refugees, with only 67,000 actually arriving. The 10% target represents the UN's estimate of highly vulnerable refugees needing resettlement. According to Oxfam's analysis, only Canada, Germany, and Norway have exceeded their "fair share" of resettlement, with five additional countries pledging over half their allocation. In contrast, the UK is set to take 22% of its fair share, the US 7%, and France merely 4%. Oxfam GB's chief executive Mark Goldring condemned the widespread failure to provide safe havens for the most vulnerable Syrian refugees.

Newsweek will publish its final print edition on December 31st, reflecting the broader media shift towards digital platforms as traditional advertising revenues decline. Two years ago, the magazine merged with the online news group Daily Beast, whose founder Tina Brown reported over 15 million monthly unique visitors, representing a 70% increase from the previous year. In a statement, Brown acknowledged the emotional difficulty of leaving print behind while embracing digital transformation. Founded in 1933, Newsweek has witnessed significant changes in news consumption, with subscriber numbers dropping from a peak of 3 million to 1.5 million today. Falling print advertising and changing consumer habits have prompted the transition to Newsweek Global, a digital-only subscription service targeting the growing tablet market, which has expanded from 13 million to 70 million users in the United States. While the digital landscape offers opportunities, analysts warn of intense competition and the challenge of distinguishing oneself online. Brown emphasized that the decision stems from economic pressures rather than a decline in journalistic quality. Once the second-largest US news weekly behind Time, Newsweek struggled with diminishing circulation and profitability. Sold by the Washington Post Company to Sidney Harman in 2010 and subsequently merged with the Daily Beast, the publication continues to adapt to the evolving media environment.

Spencer Flower denied that his connection with a social housing organization was pertinent to a 2013 debate about housing in east Dorset. However, he was convicted of illegally voting on a matter where his company could potentially benefit from the proposed plan. The 72-year-old Conservative councillor will retain his public office position. Flower, from Verwood, Dorset, received a six-month conditional discharge and was ordered to pay £930 in costs. A district judge at Bournemouth Magistrates' Court determined he had violated provisions of the Localism Act 2011. Outside the court, Flower declined to discuss his political future, expressing surprise at the verdict and emphasizing the court's recognition of his lack of personal gain or intentional wrongdoing. As a non-executive director of Synergy Housing Ltd, Flower earned an annual allowance of approximately £5,000 and voted in February 2013 on East Dorset's core strategy, which involved potential redevelopment in Wimborne. Although he declared his charitable interest before the meeting, he was found guilty of participating in the vote without reasonable justification. While no specific planning permission had been submitted, there was speculation that Synergy's social housing might benefit from developer Wyatt's plans. Flower was charged in November and stepped down as Dorset County Council leader to address the allegations. Two additional charges regarding undisclosed interests in Zebra Property Solutions Ltd were previously withdrawn. A council spokesperson confirmed Flower remains an East Dorset District Council member and noted that election nominations are still open.

David Bowie's final album, Blackstar, maintained its top position for a third week, with Best of Bowie, Hunky Dory, and Ziggy Stardust also appearing in the Top 10. Adele held steady at number two, while Suede, heavily influenced by Bowie, secured the highest new entry at number six. Rihanna's Anti failed to chart after its Thursday release, deemed ineligible due to being freely distributed on Tidal, which violates Official Chart Company rules for top 40 inclusion. However, Rihanna did make the singles chart with Work, her Drake collaboration, entering at 13 after just 48 hours. The top new entry at three was Jonas Blue's tropical dance remake of Tracy Chapman's Fast Car, featuring Dakota, surpassing the original's 1988 and 2011 chart performances. Blue shared on Facebook that he wanted to recreate a song his mother frequently played during his childhood. Shawn Mendes remained number one with Stitches, selling 13,000 more copies than Justin Bieber's Love Yourself and becoming the most streamed track with 3.51 million plays. Elle King's Graham Norton Show appearance propelled Ex's & Oh's from 64 to 15, while her album Love Stuff climbed 40 places to number 18. Additional Bowie albums in the top 40 included Nothing Has Changed (5), Heroes (28), Diamond Dogs (30), Station to Station (32), and Scary Monsters (36).

Mr Joshua informed his congregation on Sunday that he "saw" a woman emerging victorious. Following Donald Trump's decisive victory on Tuesday, visitors to the preacher's Facebook page noticed the prophecy had vanished. The affluent pastor, known as "the prophet" to his numerous followers, is among Nigeria's most prominent and influential evangelists, with popularity spanning Africa and attracting many high-profile politicians. The US election prediction was aired on Mr Joshua's TV channel Emmanuel TV and subsequently uploaded to YouTube. A portion of that "prophecy" was initially posted on the preacher's Facebook page but subsequently removed. "Ten days ago I saw the president of America with a narrow win... What I frankly saw was a woman," the original post stated. TB Joshua has been trending on Twitter across Nigeria, Ghana, and South Africa, with people sharing memes mocking his prediction. Individuals also commented on his Wednesday Facebook post to express their views. Some followers remained loyal, with South African Gugu Mathonsi declaring, "I will always believe in your prophesies, through thick and thin," while others questioned the deletion. Many continue to believe TB Joshua possesses supernatural powers, including healing and prophetic abilities, with several African political leaders having previously sought his guidance.

Participants in the annual competition are given five minutes to craft the most convincing and elaborate lie possible. This year's winner, George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria, was taken aback by his victory while battling a chest infection. His winning tale involved encountering Donald Trump and his wife in an underwater hotel, which stemmed from a story about constructing a small submarine from his father's old bubble car. He described a journey to the Isle of Man where they encountered famous personalities in a Scottish submarine fashioned from shortbread tins, with Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond allegedly selling these unique vessels to the United States. Last year's champion, Mike Naylor, nicknamed Monkey Liar from Wasdale, secured second place, while Helen Jordan claimed third. Previous winners include comedian Sue Perkins, who won in 2006, and the competition has even attracted international participants, with one entrant traveling from Germany in 2014. Hosted at the Bridge Inn in Santon Bridge, the event features a panel of judges and an audience. Politicians and legal professionals are excluded from participating, deemed too skilled in fabrication. The contest, honoring legendary storyteller Will Ritson, a Wasdale landlord from the 19th century, commemorates his famous tall tales, such as claiming local turnips were so massive they required quarrying and could serve as sheep sheds.

Mark Footitt's impressive 3-52 saw the visitors lose five wickets before lunch, with Sam Curran dismissing England opener Haseeb Hameed for a second-ball duck. However, Clark's magnificent unbeaten 108 from 133 balls and Shivnarine Chanderpaul's steady 85 not out reconstructed the visitor's innings. Clark reached his century with a massive pulled six near the day's end. The retired West Indies international Chanderpaul formed a 55-run partnership with Ryan McLaren, stabilizing the innings after the early wickets, before being joined by Clark when Gareth Batty dismissed McLaren. The pair then shared an unbroken 172-run stand, with Clark - batting at number eight - quickly surpassing Chanderpaul's score and reaching his half-century first. Although bad light halted play during the evening session, it did not impede Clark's progress. The 26-year-old, whose previous highest score was 84 not out, struck 17 fours and three sixes. Lancashire's turnaround was particularly remarkable considering they were five wickets down within 22 overs. Footitt, who took eight wickets in Surrey's season opener against Warwickshire, dismissed opener Alex Davies, stand-in captain Liam Livingstone, and Dane Vilas, while the Curran brothers claimed a wicket each during the early onslaught. Clark later told BBC Radio Lancashire about his extraordinary performance and the team's potential for the following day.

Ikea's annual sales reached â‚¬34.2bn (Â£28.8bn) in August, with the company expanding by 12 new stores and achieving a 7.1% sales increase, which was lower than the previous year's 11% growth. Like-for-like store sales rose 5%, maintaining the same performance as the previous year. The Swedish retailer reported particularly strong performance in Poland, with sales jumping approximately 20%, making it the fastest-growing market. Germany remained the largest market, closely followed by the United States, with Australia and Canada also performing well. The company plans to launch its first stores in India and Serbia this year, bringing its total global outlets to 340 across 28 countries. However, expansion into Russia has been paused due to unresolved legal disputes. In the UK, Ikea operates 19 stores and plans to open new locations in Exeter, Sheffield, and southeast London. Alongside store openings, the company introduced 19 "click and collect" outlets worldwide, responding to changing consumer preferences. Ikea has recently begun offering online sales with home delivery or collection options, diverging from its traditional self-service model. Online furniture market sales in the UK increased by 15% last year, representing over 12% of total expenditure. The company's CEO previously projected annual sales of â‚¬50bn by 2020 and recently opened a museum in Almhult, Sweden, showcasing the brand's history and iconic designs, including its famous meatballs and bookshelves.

John Hinckley Jr., who attempted to assassinate President Ronald Reagan in 1981, has been granted unconditional release after decades of psychiatric treatment. The shooting, which occurred early in Reagan's presidency, critically wounded the president and seriously injured his press secretary James Brady, who later died in 2014. Hinckley was initially found not guilty by reason of insanity and was committed to a psychiatric hospital. After years of treatment and gradual supervised releases, a judge determined that Hinckley no longer posed a threat to himself or others, based on medical assessments showing no active mental illness symptoms since 1983. During the assassination attempt, Hinckley had targeted Reagan in an obsessive attempt to impress actress Jodie Foster. The incident also wounded two law enforcement officers. Reagan was shot in the lung but recovered, while Brady suffered permanent brain damage and used a wheelchair for the remainder of his life. The court's detailed order outlines Hinckley's psychiatric history and the conditions of his release, marking a significant milestone in a case that shocked the nation decades ago.

Emcol 2008 Ltd, the company operating the Haverfordwest abattoir, went bankrupt in January 2016, leaving behind £660,000 in debts owed to over 230 creditors. A company director attributed the collapse to rising operational expenses and outstanding payments. Newport dairy farmer John Sollis described the situation as a "disaster" for local creditors. Companies House documents reveal that one livestock trader is owed more than £107,000, with other creditors facing substantial five-figure losses. Liquidator Gary Stones noted that unsecured creditor payments were entirely contingent on recovering an Irish book debt. The report indicated Emcol was owed nearly £470,000 by an Irish company. Sollis, personally owed almost £15,000, highlighted the broader impact, explaining that farmers now must transport livestock and injured animals further, increasing costs. The nearest abattoir is now in Cross Hands, Carmarthenshire. NFU Cymru President Stephen James, owed over £1,000, emphasized the significant disruption, particularly for handling injured livestock, which now must be shot on farms. Director Helen Lewis acknowledged the company's financial challenges, citing substantial outstanding payments from an Irish firm and escalating abattoir operational costs. She expressed sympathy for the affected farmers, many of whom she knew personally.

Ben Purdy, an 18-year-old, was fatally shot in the head in Bermondsey after challenging his girlfriend's ex-partner about intimidating messages sent following their breakup. Andrew Bayne, 37, from Trundleys Terrace, and his nephew Michael Bagnall, 22, from Hospital Way, both in Lewisham, were found guilty of murder. Their sentencing is scheduled for 20 November at the Old Bailey. The court was told that Mr Purdy and two friends - Callum Malone and Jack Walker - confronted Bagnall, and afterward, the defendants drove around Bermondsey searching for Mr Purdy. Upon locating him in Mossington Gardens, Andrew Bayne shot Mr Purdy in the head and then aimed the weapon at Callum before fleeing. Mr Purdy sustained fatal injuries and died the following day. Despite Bagnall having a new girlfriend, prosecutor Crispin Aylett QC explained that he remained aggrieved by her moving on and sent threatening messages via phone and Facebook. Mr Aylett noted that Ben and his friends decided to confront Bagnall, calling it an unquestionably foolish decision that ultimately cost Purdy his life. Bayne was additionally convicted of possessing a gun with intent, and Bagnall of affray. As the guilty verdicts were announced, Michael Bagnall became disruptive in the dock and was subsequently removed by officers.

Masai Graham clinched the top spot with the winning quip: "My dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart." The festival's comedic gems were carefully selected by a panel of 10 judges and then presented to 2,000 voters who chose their preferred joke. Previous champions like Tim Vine, Stewart Francis, and Zoe Lyon had also triumphed in this competition, which is hosted by TV channel Dave. Graham, hailing from West Bromwich, secured victory after being shortlisted in both 2014 and 2015, remarking, "It's an incredible honour to land Joke of the Fringe. Not bad for someone from West Brom!" Comedian Stuart Mitchell claimed second place with his joke: "Why is it old people say 'there's no place like home', yet when you put them in one..." The judges endured an average of 60 comedy performances and sifted through over 3,600 minutes of material before making their selections. To ensure an unbiased evaluation, the comic's identity and show details were concealed during voting. Dave's general manager, Steve North, highlighted the Fringe's reputation for discovering emerging comedy talent, noting the exciting mix of new and returning performers. Voters also had the opportunity to select the most "groan-worthy" jokes, including Adam Hess' "In France, J-Lo is called 'I have water'", and Darren Walsh's "What do you call three members of Abba in a French slaughterhouse? Abba trois."

The Halle Orchestra plans to establish a school in Stoke-on-Trent by 2020, catering to both primary and secondary students. Collaborating with an academy trust, the orchestra aims to leverage music as a tool to enhance academic performance. Chief executive John Summers emphasized the project's goal of elevating students' aspirations across various subjects. Pending Department for Education approval, the proposed free school would welcome students aged seven to 19, offering unique musical experiences including masterclasses, concert access, and artist residencies. Students would dedicate 40% of their time to specialized music education, working closely with the Halle Choir, Halle Youth Orchestra, and Halle for Youth. Summers highlighted the orchestra's extensive expertise in high-level performance and instrumental coaching, believing that musical training can support academic achievement. This concept is not unprecedented, drawing inspiration from a successful model in Bremen, Germany, where a renowned orchestra integrated its rehearsal spaces into a comprehensive school. In that instance, the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen's presence significantly reduced truancy rates and improved academic outcomes.

Leading the procession were survivors and those impacted by the suicide bombings at Belgium's airport and metro station, which claimed 32 lives. The Belgian broadcaster characterized the march as "calm and silent". Originally scheduled a week after the 22 March attacks, officials postponed the event due to security concerns. Victims' relatives, paramedics, airport staff, and representatives from various religious backgrounds participated in Sunday's march. Mourners carried flowers to commemorate those who perished. The procession traversed through the Molenbeek neighbourhood - home to many individuals allegedly involved in Brussels and Paris attacks - and concluded at the makeshift memorial near the city's stock exchange. Hassan Bousetta, one of the march's organizers, told AFP: "When defenseless civilians are brutally attacked, all citizens must unite to express their disgust and solidarity." The turnout was less than half of the anticipated 15,000 participants. The Islamic State militant group claimed responsibility for the Brussels attacks, as well as the November 13 Paris attacks that killed 130 people. While Belgian police have conducted numerous arrests in recent weeks, European security agencies remain under scrutiny for alleged intelligence failures and missed opportunities to prevent the terror cell's operations.

Senegalese government officials have approved Cairn's evaluation plan for offshore exploration. The company, which discovered two potential fields last year, believes the area could hold over a billion barrels of oil. Its evaluation will commence with a 3D seismic survey, followed by a multi-well exploration and appraisal programme later this year. Cairn holds a 40% stake in three offshore blocks, with ConocoPhillips owning 35%, FAR Ltd 15%, and Petrosen 10% during the exploration phase. In its half-yearly report, Cairn also disclosed initiating international arbitration with India's government over a tax dispute. Indian authorities have blocked Cairn from accessing its 10% shareholding in Cairn India Limited. In March, the company received a $1.6bn tax bill for 2006-07, which it contests. Cairn plans to seek compensation for losses from its declining CIL stake, which dropped from $1bn in December 2013 to $526m by June. This valuation reduction led to a $177.1m impairment loss and a post-tax loss of $230m, compared to $62m the previous year. Despite generating no revenue due to its focus on exploration, Cairn maintains a cash balance of $725m. The company's share price fell approximately 5% on Tuesday morning.

Security forces deployed tear gas and live ammunition to disperse predominantly Shia Muslim protesters challenging government corruption and security shortcomings. A temporary curfew was implemented and subsequently lifted in Baghdad. This marks the second instance this month where demonstrators breached the government district. Prominent Shia cleric Moqtada Sadr denounced the violent response and supported the protesters' "peaceful and spontaneous revolt". Approximately 50 demonstrators reportedly sustained injuries. Protesters accuse the government of neglecting crucial reforms while simultaneously battling the Islamic State group and managing declining oil revenues. Some demonstrators infiltrated the prime minister's office and parliament within the Green Zone, which houses key government buildings and foreign embassies. Authorities later confirmed they had regained complete control of the area. Sadr, whose Mehdi Army gained prominence following the 2003 US invasion, has a complex political history marked by anti-US sentiment and sectarian conflicts. Despite previously being associated with violent confrontations, he has more recently advocated for Iraqi unity. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi, who assumed power in 2014, has struggled to implement reforms due to parliamentary gridlock. Iraq's government allocation system remains deeply problematic, with the country ranking 161st out of 168 on Transparency International's corruption perceptions index.

A Muslim cleric from Stoke-on-Trent, Mehboob Akhtar, was sentenced alongside nine other individuals, including his wife and daughter, for fraudulently obtaining nearly £1m in property through deceptive mortgage applications. At Birmingham Crown Court, the 60-year-old was handed a 14-year prison sentence after being convicted of 11 charges, including five counts of conspiracy to commit fraud and cheating HMRC out of £271,000. The court revealed that Akhtar, also known as Saint Pirwali Pandariman, orchestrated the conspiracy over more than a decade from 2003 to 2014. Despite being a prominent faith leader from Pakistan who had raised millions for poverty relief through the Darbar Unique Centre, the judge criticized him for exploiting his spiritual status. Akhtar strategically kept his name off most documentation, instead using his wife, daughter, and niece to apply for mortgages. Police investigations in September 2012 uncovered forged documents and emails related to the scheme. His wife Khadija received four years and three months, while his daughter Rushbamani was sentenced to three-and-a-half years. Seven additional individuals, including two mortgage brokers, were also sentenced for various fraud-related charges. Staffordshire Police described the case as a "very long and complex investigation" following the sentencing.

Jade Jones, a 23-year-old taekwondo athlete from north Wales, is set to defend her Olympic title in the -57kg category at Rio 2016. Inspired by athletes like Kelly Holmes, she reflects on becoming a role model herself and notes the increased participation of girls in the sport. Jones began taekwondo at 15, encouraged by her grandfather to stay active, and has witnessed a significant growth in female participation. As the world number one in her weight category, she has won a World Grand Prix and two European titles since her London 2012 victory. Jones made history as Britain's youngest and first Olympic taekwondo champion by defeating China's double world champion Yuzhuo Hou. Despite experiencing fluctuating motivation over the past four years, she remains focused on winning another gold medal. Recalling her unexpected rise to success after joining the national team just two years before the London Olympics, Jones emphasizes that her primary goal has always been Olympic glory. Her journey highlights the increasing opportunities for women in sports and the power of inspiration.

Remus Hamza, a 40-year-old Romanian resident of Cardiff, is accused of sexually assaulting a 20-year-old woman near Cardiff University after she left her friends during a night out on 20 September. At Newport Crown Court, the prosecution argued that the victim was too intoxicated to provide consent to sexual activity. According to the prosecution, the woman was walking home alone around 02:00 GMT, passing through Greyfriars Road, an underpass by City Hall, and Museum Avenue, when Hamza allegedly approached and attacked her behind a bush. Prosecutor Claire Pickthall told the jury that the victim was so drunk she couldn't recall the incident or the sexual encounter. Lee Neill, a witness, became suspicious after seeing Hamza walking with the victim near the National Museum of Wales and followed them, taking a photograph as potential evidence. The camera flash startled Hamza, causing him to flee. Neill chased him but lost him and returned to the victim, subsequently calling the police. Initially, the confused victim mistakenly identified Neill as her attacker, leading to his temporary arrest. Subsequent DNA evidence led police to Hamza. During her testimony, the woman confirmed consuming wine, cider, and cocktails, stating she couldn't remember much about her journey home or the attack and emphasized she would never willingly have sex with a stranger, asserting she has a "moral compass".

Helen Bailey, 51, was discovered deceased in a cess pit at her Royston, Hertfordshire residence in July 2016, having been missing since 11 April. Her fiancé, Ian Stewart, maintains his innocence regarding the murder. Edward Farmer initially told St Albans Crown Court he spotted her in a car in Broadstairs, Kent, between mid-April and June, but later conceded the sighting might have occurred weeks earlier. The jury heard his account of seeing Ms Bailey on Charlotte Street near her holiday home, apparently driving a dark-colored Range Rover or similar 4x4, and that she was alone. This contradicted defence claims she had been kidnapped by two violent men. When pressed about the timing, Mr Farmer suggested the sighting was approximately five or six weeks before his police interview on 13 July. Ms Bailey was reported missing by Mr Stewart on 15 April. Under prosecution cross-examination, Mr Farmer acknowledged the potential sighting could have been in March, well before her disappearance was reported. He also admitted having no particular reason to recall the sighting until contacted by a The Sun reporter in June. Mr Stewart, 56, from Baldock Road, Royston, Hertfordshire, faces charges of drugging and suffocating his partner before disposing of her body in the garage pit. He denies murder, preventing lawful burial, fraud, and three counts of perverting the course of justice. The trial is ongoing.

The Republican attempted to dismiss the comment, which was initiated by a supporter claiming: "We have a problem in this country - it's called Muslims". The remarks were made during a campaign rally for Mr Trump in New Hampshire. Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton described his failure to condemn "hateful rhetoric" as "disturbing and wrong". Addressing his first questioner at the campaign event in Rochester, the billionaire businessman said: "I like this guy." "We have a problem in this country called Muslims," the man stated. "We know our current president is one. You know he's not even an American." "We need this question?" Mr Trump said, chuckling. "But anyway," the man continued, "we have training camps growing where they want to kill us. That's my question: When can we get rid of them?" Mr Trump did not clarify that Mr Obama is a Christian American, instead responding that "bad things are happening" and saying he would investigate. Mrs Clinton criticized Mr Trump on social media, tweeting: "Donald Trump not denouncing false statements about POTUS & hateful rhetoric about Muslims is disturbing & just plain wrong. Cut it out." Democratic National Committee chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz stated that Mr Trump's "racism knows no bounds". Mr Trump's campaign manager Corey Lewandowski downplayed the incident, telling US media that "all he heard was a question about training camps". "The media wants to make this issue about Obama. The bigger issue is that Obama is waging a war against Christians in this country," Mr Lewandowski told the Washington Post. The incident recalled a moment during the 2008 campaign when Republican nominee John McCain took the microphone away from a woman who said she did not trust Mr Obama because he was "an Arab". President Obama, who has spoken openly about his Christian faith, was born to an American mother and Kenyan father in Hawaii. Mr Trump had been a leading skeptic, challenging Mr Obama in 2011 to produce his birth certificate to disprove rumors that he was born in Kenya, which the president did. With more than a year until polling day, the businessman leads his Republican rivals in polls despite having no political experience.

Jeremy Corbyn is adapting to media scrutiny and presenting his distinctive political platform. He has strongly criticized the government's handling of the Calais migrant crisis, advocating for greater UK involvement. "These are human beings in desperate situations who need our help and support," he stated, emphasizing the importance of participating in European refugee programs for Syrians and others. His immigration stance sharply contrasts with UKIP leader Nigel Farage's perspective, who questioned government planning capabilities without precise population projections. Conservative MP Damian Green also warns against open-door immigration, but Corbyn maintains that immigration significantly benefits the UK. He argues that immigrants have enhanced the nation's health service, education, and industrial development, creating a vibrant cosmopolitan society. Rather than fearing immigration, he believes people should embrace its opportunities. At the upcoming Labour conference in Brighton, Corbyn aims to address key issues like housing shortages, infrastructure investment, and opposition to benefits reform. His primary challenge is reconnecting with Labour supporters, particularly in the South East who previously abandoned the party. Despite acknowledging the difficulty, Corbyn remains optimistic about winning back these voters and is eager to engage in this political struggle during the conference from September 27-30.

Two backpackers, Miss Witheridge, 23, from Norfolk, and Mr Miller, 24, from Jersey, were discovered dead on a beach at Koh Tao in September 2014. Burmese bar workers Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Tun were convicted of their murders in December 2015, with an appeal court in Thailand subsequently confirming their death sentences. The men's lawyers now have 30 days to submit a final appeal to Thailand's Supreme Court. The defendants' mothers previously filed appeals at Koh Samui court, expressing concerns about the judicial process, particularly regarding the DNA evidence. Andy Hall, a legal advisor for the families, stated that there remained reasonable doubt about the men's responsibility for the 2014 incident. Miss Witheridge, a University of Essex student from Hemsby, and Mr Miller, a civil and structural engineering graduate, were found brutally beaten on the beach. A post-mortem revealed Miss Witheridge had been sexually assaulted. Prosecutors argued DNA evidence from cigarette butts, a condom, and the victims' bodies connected Lin and Phyo to the killings. The accused, who are from Myanmar, denied their initial confessions, claiming police torture. Their legal team contended that DNA from the alleged murder weapon did not match the defendants and argued that evidence was mishandled, suggesting the confessions resulted from systematic abuse of migrant workers.

The report by the Institute for Economics and Peace (IEP) revealed that the economic impact of global violence is equivalent to the combined economies of Brazil, Canada, France, Germany, Spain, and the United Kingdom. The annual report highlighted a widening gap between the most and least peaceful nations, with Iceland ranking as the most peaceful and Syria as the least. Libya experienced the most significant deterioration in 2014, and the Middle East and North Africa emerged as the world's most violent region, surpassing South Asia. Conflict-related deaths increased from 49,000 in 2010 to 180,000 in 2014, while terrorism-related fatalities rose by 61% in 2013, claiming nearly 18,000 lives primarily in Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Nigeria, and Syria. IEP Chief Executive Steve Killelea emphasized the "inequality with peace" globally, noting that Western European countries have achieved historically low murder rates and security expenditures. In contrast, countries like Iraq, Syria, Nigeria, South Sudan, and the Central African Republic became more violent. The report stated that conflict costs represented 13.4% of global GDP, with significant increases in expenses related to internal conflicts, displaced people, refugee support, UN peacekeeping, and conflict-induced GDP losses. The cost of supporting approximately 50 million refugees and internally displaced persons has surged 267% since 2008 to $128 billion. If global violence were to decrease by 10%, it could potentially inject $1.43 trillion into the world economy - more than six times Greece's debt and three times the total earnings of 1.1 billion of the world's poorest people.

Falcon and Pointer was penalized £175,000 for making automated calls about PPI, while Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd received a £50,000 fine for attempting to contact deceased relatives. Both companies claimed the calls were made by a third party. Anne Jones, Assistant Commissioner for Wales, emphasized that this sends a "clear message to callous cold-callers". She noted that Swansea appears to be the UK's cold-call capital, with companies using ruthless business models based on illicit practices to make intrusive and distressing calls. The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) has taken action against six companies since 2013. Falcon and Pointer had its licence revoked in January 2016 and claimed to have stopped making calls in June 2015, but an investigation revealed they made an additional two million calls in the following two months. Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd, a windows, doors, and conservatories business, received 168 complaints in six months. Ms Jones stressed that their action demonstrates the consequences for cold-callers operating in Swansea who disregard legal requirements. Sandra Busby from the Welsh Contact Centre Forum acknowledged that while legitimate companies have a place in the market, unethical businesses damage the industry's reputation. The ICO's latest action coincided with the publication of updated Direct Marketing Guidance to help organizations understand and follow best practices.

A walkout is underway to protest the dismissal of two nurses, Kevin Gregson and Peter Hilton, who were fired after a confrontation with a patient at Ashworth high-security hospital. The Prison Officers' Association (POA) argues the nurses used "reasonable force" during an incident where the patient was reportedly aggressive, headbutting a colleague and spitting at staff. Mersey Care Trust maintains that based on the evidence, terminating the nurses was their only viable option. The dispute began at 07:00 GMT, with the POA's general secretary Steve Gillan claiming the public would be sympathetic to the nurses' actions. The trust expressed disappointment with the union's decision to strike before an independent employment tribunal can hear the case, emphasizing their commitment to caring for complex and vulnerable patients. They stressed that staff dismissal is not taken lightly and that their decision was based on careful consideration of the available evidence. Ashworth is one of three high-security psychiatric hospitals in England and Wales, alongside Rampton in Nottinghamshire and Broadmoor in Berkshire.

Charles Blackman's oil painting Women Lovers depicts two nude women resting on a bed alongside a cat. Art broker Mossgreen attempted to promote the artwork on Facebook, but the social media platform rejected the post for allegedly advertising adult content. Mossgreen's chief executive Paul Summer criticized the decision as absurd, telling the BBC that the image was a beautiful artwork without sexual overtones. Facebook maintained its stance, stating that such ads lead to negative user sentiment and that their decision was final, though Mossgreen subsequently reposted the image. The artwork was expected to fetch over A$45,000 at auction, with Summer questioning who Facebook was protecting, noting that his teenage daughters would find the censorship ridiculous. Blackman, now 88, is considered a significant figure from a pivotal era in Australian art, with contemporaries including Arthur Boyd, Sidney Nolan, and Albert Tucker. His painting The Game of Chess sold for A$1.78m at Sotheby's Australia last year, and Summer described Blackman as the most respected living Australian artist. A similar incident occurred recently when a French teacher challenged Facebook for suspending his account over a 19th-century nude painting by Gustave Courbet.

The Spy Who Came In From The Cold, set during the Cold War's peak, is being adapted by Simon Beaufoy, the Oscar-winning writer of Slumdog Millionaire. The series follows Alec Leamas, a British intelligence officer whose East Berlin network has collapsed. Le Carre expressed enthusiasm about the BBC One production, which will be another collaboration with AMC, similar to their successful The Night Manager. That previous series saw Tom Hiddleston, Hugh Laurie, and Olivia Colman win Golden Globes and receive a best mini-series nomination. Set in 1962, shortly after the Berlin Wall's construction, the story depicts Leamas's agents either dead or fleeing from East German counter-intelligence officer Hans-Dieter Mundt. Recalled to London, Leamas is offered a chance for revenge. Originally a 1963 novel adapted into a 1965 film starring Richard Burton, Le Carre is eager to see this new adaptation. He highlighted his confidence in the team, while Beaufoy described it as the ultimate Cold War spy narrative. The Ink Factory, producers of The Night Manager, will create the series with Character 7. BBC Drama's Piers Wenger celebrated the opportunity to bring this legendary spy thriller back to television following their previous international success.

Oxford University Press conducted an analysis of over 120,421 short stories by children aged five to 13, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. The research revealed that while technology remains central to children's lives, their writing about it is rapidly evolving. Traditional technological terms like email, mobile, and Facebook are declining, replaced by Instagram, Snapchat, and emoji. "Television" has been replaced by "phone" in children's narratives. A notable trend is the widespread use of the hashtag (#) as an editorial device to add drama or commentary to sentences. Technological references have shifted from iPod, mp3, and Blackberry to iPhone, WhatsApp, and ooVoo. A prevalent storyline involves achieving sudden internet fame through YouTube videos, with children focusing on views, shares, and likes. Popular characters ranged from fairy tale figures like Cinderella and Snow White to athletes like Lionel Messi and Wayne Rooney, with surprising inclusions of mythological characters such as Zeus and Hercules. World events like World War One, Ukraine, Syria, and Ebola featured prominently, with many stories exploring potential cures. Creative new words emerged, including inventive terms like "wellysaurus" and "Stegasuarez". The competition winners were set to be announced on The Chris Evans Breakfast Show on BBC Radio 2, with the Duchess of Cornwall's support.

The 23-year-old Heracles forward maintained he was awaiting confirmation of a move to the Championship side. Slade refuted the reports but acknowledged previous interest in the player "some time ago". "To my knowledge, this is not something we'll pursue," he stated. Netherlands Under-21 international Weghorst began his career with FC Emmen before joining Heracles in 2014. Heracles chairman Jam Smit believed a fee had been negotiated with Cardiff for Weghorst, who had also been linked with Celtic. "I think the speculation surrounding the player has originated from the Netherlands," Slade added. "There was an initial inquiry some time ago. That's all I can comment on." Slade hoped to make up to three signings during the transfer window to support Cardiff's play-off ambitions, with the club currently four points from the top six. A striker was likely to be recruited following Kenwyne Jones's departure to Al Jazira in the United Arab Emirates. The Trinidad and Tobago international claimed on social media that the club had not offered him a new contract, but Slade disputed this, saying, "I'm confident discussions occurred between Kenwyne's representatives, Kenwyne himself, Ken Choo, and the board." He also dismissed Rotherham Manager Neil Redfearn's claims about potential transfer talks for Alex Revell. Revell, 32, had joined Cardiff from Rotherham in January 2015 and scored twice in 15 league appearances. "We've already lost a target-type centre forward," Slade noted. "We must ensure we don't compromise our squad and maintain sufficient coverage in every position." Cardiff were set to host League One Shrewsbury Town in the FA Cup third round, with defender Lee Peltier uncertain due to illness.

NHS England aims to reduce doctor appointments and antibiotic overuse through a new walk-in service. The scheme could potentially save millions by decreasing GP visits. Pharmacies have raised concerns about potential funding cuts that might impact the initiative. The Sore Throat Test and Treat service, trialled in 35 Boots pharmacies, uses a throat swab to quickly determine whether an illness is viral or bacterial. Within five minutes, the test can identify if antibiotics are necessary, allowing pharmacists to prescribe medication without a GP consultation. NHS chief executive Simon Stevens plans to expand the service nationwide over the next year. Microbiologist Dr Adam Roberts praised the approach, highlighting its potential to reduce inappropriate antibiotic use. Of 360 participants in the trial, only 36 received prescriptions, demonstrating significant potential for reducing unnecessary medication. Claire Ward from Pharmacy Voice welcomed the initiative but warned that service cuts could undermine its effectiveness. The throat test is part of eight medical innovations designed to modernize the NHS amid increasing demand. Sir Bruce Keogh, NHS England's national medical director, emphasized that innovation is crucial for building a sustainable healthcare system that delivers better value and improves patient interactions.

Researchers from the University of Bristol warn of a "growing threat" from the Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island. Located 49 km from the Sendai nuclear plant and near Kagoshima, a city of 600,000, the volcano last caused deadly destruction in 1914, killing 58 people. Situated on the Pacific "Ring of fire", Japan has over 100 volcanoes, with Sakurajima frequently emitting ash and experiencing small explosions, most recently in February. Japanese authorities closely monitor the volcano, which is at Level 3 in the volcanic warning system, prohibiting people from approaching it. Dr. James Hickey, now at the University of Exeter's Camborne School of Mines, noted that the 1914 eruption measured about 1.5 cubic kilometers, and based on current data, another similar-sized eruption could occur in about 25 years. A joint report by Bristol University and the Sakurajima Volcano Research Centre revealed that 14 million cubic metres of magma accumulate annually, equivalent to filling Wembley Stadium 3.5 times. The researchers suggest that magma is accumulating faster than it can be expelled through smaller eruptions, indicating a potential major eruption within the next 30 years. Using innovative modeling techniques, scientists hope these findings will help authorities prepare for potential disasters. Dr. Haruhisa Nakamichi from Kyoto University confirmed that Kagoshima city has already developed new evacuation plans, acknowledging that less than 30 years remain before the expected significant eruption.
